title: 108_s1279
content: The Act titled "Disaster Area Health and Environmental Monitoring Act of 2003" aims to protect the health and safety of individuals in a disaster area by amending Title IV of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. This includes the addition of a new section, 409, focused on ensuring the well-being of individuals in disaster-affected areas. The new section 409 of the Act defines an "individual" broadly to include various workers and volunteers responding to disasters, those involved in cleanup and restoration of critical infrastructure, and residents of disaster areas. The new section 409 of the Act broadly defines an "individual" to include workers, volunteers, residents of disaster areas, and those involved in cleanup and restoration of critical infrastructure. The term "program" refers to activities carried out for a disaster area, and "substance of concern" pertains to chemicals or substances associated with potential health effects heightened by a disaster. If the President determines substances of concern are released in a disaster area, a program may be carried out for protection, assessment, monitoring, and study of individuals' health and safety. This includes informing and protecting individuals against health impacts, monitoring their health over time, and conducting clinical examinations for short- and long-term effects of the substances. A program may be implemented to protect, assess, monitor, and study the health and safety of individuals in a disaster area. This includes collecting environmental exposure data, providing health care referrals, conducting clinical examinations, and using information to prevent future health impacts. The program aims to protect individuals in a disaster area by establishing an exposure registry, studying health impacts, and providing assistance for health coverage. Activities should be timely for public health protection. Participation in registries and studies is encouraged. The program under paragraph (1) is voluntary, with measures in place to protect participant privacy. The President may collaborate with medical institutions for program implementation, selecting based on specific criteria. The program is voluntary and protects participant privacy. The President may collaborate with a consortium of medical institutions near the disaster area, with experience in environmental health, toxicology, and safety, to develop clinical protocols and conduct health examinations. The President shall involve interested and affected parties in establishing and maintaining a program for health monitoring, mental health studies, and medical surveillance programs. The President shall involve various stakeholders in health monitoring programs, including government agencies, disaster responders, local residents, businesses, schools, healthcare providers, and other organizations. Involvement may be through advisory committees. Privacy regulations must be followed in program implementation. The President or designated medical institutions must submit reports to relevant government agencies and Congress every 5 years on programs and studies conducted under the health monitoring program established. The National Academy of Sciences will report on disaster area health and environmental protection and monitoring. The Secretary of Homeland Security, Health and Human Services, and EPA will contract the National Academy of Sciences for a study on disaster area health and environmental protection. The report will involve experts in various fields including environmental health, medicine, toxicology, and emergency planning. The report will provide advice and recommendations on emergency planning, public outreach, health departments, environmental protection, disaster response, and public health services. It will focus on monitoring and responding to chemical releases in disaster areas to protect public health and safety. The report will focus on emergency planning, public outreach, health departments, environmental protection, disaster response, and public health services. It includes guidelines for collecting samples in disasters, analyzing samples, setting health-based thresholds, and sharing monitoring results with government agencies. The curr_chunk discusses the responsibilities of government agencies, appropriate response personnel, and the public in disaster response. It also addresses the capabilities of Federal, State, and local agencies in collecting and analyzing samples, reporting results, and taking response actions. Additionally, it mentions the Federal Government's capacity for environmental monitoring in the event of a disaster or terrorist attack. Authorization of Appropriations is granted for the Environmental Protection Agency to carry out necessary actions. SEC. 4. PREDISASTER HAZARD MITIGATION. Amendment to the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to change the deadline from December 31, 2003, to September 30, 2006.
